data.name: Equational reasoning with scanl
data.description:
Using equations `scanl` can be defined as follows: ```haskell rs !! 0 = s0 rs !! (n+1) = rs !! n <+> xs !! n => rs = scanl (<+>) s0 xs ``` What that means for us is that if we can express our problem in terms of those two equations we may as well rewrite it as `scanl`. Here is an example: ```haskell fibs !! 0 = 0 fibs !! 1 = 1 fibs !! (n+1) = fibs !! n + fibs !! (n-1) {- Substitution -} fibs = 0 : rs rs !! 0 = 1 rs !! (n+1) = rs !! n + fibs !! n {- Definition of scanl -} fibs = 0 : rs rs = scanl (+) 1 fibs {- Substitution -} fibs = 0 : scanl (+) 1 fibs ```

Your task is to implement:

1) The infinite series of the successive powers of two: `[1, 2, 4, 8, 16..]` 2) Tribonacci numbers (similar to the Fibonacci numbers, but start with 3 predefined numbers): *Here you only need to use only one scanl. The second sum can be solved any other way* `[0, 0, 1, 1, 2, 4, 7, 13..]` 3) [Pell numbers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pell_number) (also similar to the Fibonacci numbers, but the previous number is summed twice instead): `[0, 1, 2, 5, 12, 29..]` *Note*: You should use provided function: ```haskell scanl :: (Int -> Int -> Int) -> Int -> [Int] -> [Int] ```
